image.altText: A court sketch of Erin Patterson.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors say it will take months to analyse computer equipment seized from the home of a woman charged with murder over a mushroom meal linked to three deaths in Victoria's east.

title.children: Erin Patterson faces court after police lay murder charges over mushroom meal

image.altText: A woman in a green shirt holding a photo of her late husband

items.synopsis: Widow Julia Evans says she reassured her late husband he was in good hands at the hospital. She now says she was very wrong.

title.children: 'Miss him dreadfully': Family sues Calvary Health Care over death of much-loved father, husband and teacher

image.altText: A red stage with Qantas logo on projector

items.synopsis: Qantas is holding its AGM, just a few days after the airline defended itself against so-called "ghost flight" allegations. Meanwhile, Australian Clinical Labs is facing a court case over a data hack last year. Read about it on our live blog.

title.children: 'Shame on you': Qantas chair shuts down shareholder question over Alan Joyce, ASX jumps after Wall Street bounce

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: APRA regulates banks, insurers and superannuation funds, and its chair John Lonsdale says cybersecurity is a key focus. He also warns that many of the big firms APRA regulates are not yet doing enough to protect customers. "We're working hard to ensure that banks, insurers and superannuation trustees have systems, processes and expertise in place to prepare for and repel cyber attacks," he says. "Many entities are still struggling with foundational issues, ensuring third party control, making sure security control testing is in place and regularly testing incident response plans. "With the potential for serious impact on millions of Australians our patience has run out."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: APRA chair says 'patience has run out' for financial firms to deal with cyber risks

children.content: APRA regulates banks, insurers and superannuation funds, and its chair John Lonsdale says cybersecurity is a key focus.
He also warns that many of the big firms APRA regulates are not yet doing enough to protect customers.
"We're working hard to ensure that banks, insurers and superannuation trustees have systems, processes and expertise in place to prepare for and repel cyber attacks," he says.
"Many entities are still struggling with foundational issues, ensuring third party control, making sure security control testing is in place and regularly testing incident response plans.
"With the potential for serious impact on millions of Australians our patience has run out."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Based on proxy votes cast ahead of today's AGM, Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has been appointed to the airline's board. Based on shareholders who cast their votes and didn't abstain, 99.2% of votes were cast in favour for her election. Doug Parker has also been elected to the Qantas vote, receiving just over 98% of votes in favour from shareholders, and Heather Smith has also been appointed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson appointed to board

children.content: Based on proxy votes cast ahead of today's AGM, Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has been appointed to the airline's board.
Based on shareholders who cast their votes and didn't abstain, 99.2% of votes were cast in favour for her election.
Doug Parker has also been elected to the Qantas vote, receiving just over 98% of votes in favour from shareholders, and Heather Smith has also been appointed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One shareholder has asked a question online about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's teenage son being granted membership to the exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge. Mr Goyder simply replied he would not be making any comment on Chairman's Lounge memberships. Qantas also responded to another question that it was confident in KPMG auditing the business despite consultancy firms being under scrutiny.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No comment' on prime minister's son being Chairman's Lounge member

children.content: One shareholder has asked a question online about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's teenage son being granted membership to the exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge.
Mr Goyder simply replied he would not be making any comment on Chairman's Lounge memberships.
Qantas also responded to another question that it was confident in KPMG auditing the business despite consultancy firms being under scrutiny.

title.children: Canberra doctor banned from practising for 12 months over offensive email to Indigenous peer

image.altText: Two men sit on an outdoor bench looking serious.

items.synopsis: Harrison and Jarad are turning their painful pasts into a legislative change campaign to remove the provision for character references when sentencing convicted paedophiles in the ACT.

title.children: These mates are on a mission to scrap character references for convicted paedophiles

image.altText: Gaza strip

items.synopsis: Seven United Nations special rapporteurs issue a warning, but Israel says it is aiming its attacks at Hamas not civilians. Follow live.

title.children: UN experts warn Palestinians are at 'grave risk of genocide' as Israel says it is making advances

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United States has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas, two US officials said. The officials spoke with Reuters on condition of anonymity. One said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week. US officials have said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 people taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in Hamas's extensive tunnel network .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US flying drones over Gaza to help find hostages

children.content: The United States has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas, two US officials said.
The officials spoke with Reuters on condition of anonymity.
One said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week.
US officials have said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 people taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in
Hamas's extensive tunnel network

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Labor minister Ed Husic has told ABC News Breakfast he believes words like genocide need to be used carefully in regards to the Israel-Gaza war. This comes after seven United Nations special rapporteurs warned that Palestinian people in Gaza were facing a "grave risk of genocide". "What we need to do is de-escalate, to calm things down and to, in particular, help those who are innocent and have been deeply affected by those actions in Gaza to be able to get that help, aid assistance in," he said. "We have called in times past, and days past, for a humanitarian ceasefire to allow aid and assistance to get through to Gaza." He said the international community was "watching very closely" and he believed there had to be a more strategic way to hold Hamas to account. "Israel's actions do matter in the way that they conduct these military operations," he said. "I think a lot of us are deeply concerned about not only the impact on innocent Palestinians but particularly on kids being affected and losing their lives in this way. "There has got to be a better way."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ed Husic cautions against using the word 'genocide'

mediaThumbnail.caption: But the minister said he's deeply concerned about the safety of innocent Palestinians in the wake of Israel's military action in Gaza.

document.caption: But the minister said he's deeply concerned about the safety of innocent Palestinians in the wake of Israel's military action in Gaza.

children.content: But the minister said he's deeply concerned about the safety of innocent Palestinians in the wake of Israel's military action in Gaza.

titleAlt.sm: Ed Husic cautions against using the word 'genocide'

children.content: Labor minister Ed Husic has told ABC News Breakfast he believes words like genocide need to be used carefully in regards to the Israel-Gaza war.
This comes after seven United Nations special rapporteurs warned that Palestinian people in Gaza were facing a "grave risk of genocide".

"What we need to do is de-escalate, to calm things down and to, in particular, help those who are innocent and have been deeply affected by those actions in Gaza to be able to get that help, aid assistance in," he said.
"We have called in times past, and days past, for a humanitarian ceasefire to allow aid and assistance to get through to Gaza."
He said the international community was "watching very closely" and he believed there had to be a more strategic way to hold Hamas to account.
"Israel's actions do matter in the way that they conduct these military operations," he said.
"I think a lot of us are deeply concerned about not only the impact on innocent Palestinians but particularly on kids being affected and losing their lives in this way.
"There has got to be a better way."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli opposition leader and former prime minister Yair Lapid has told ABC News Breakfast questions over concerns that people in Gaza are at risk of genocide should be directed at Hamas. As we reported earlier, seven United Nations special rapporteurs have warned that Palestinian people in Gaza are facing a “grave risk of genocide”. "We are worried as well, but the question should be directed at Hamas, not at us," Lapid said on ABC News Breakfast. "We didn't initiate this, we didn't want this war. "We are protecting our own people against a murderous terrorist organisation that is killing the innocent and we have no other choice. "Yes, I think the people of Gaza are in peril, the same as the people of Israel, we are all being threatened and killed by a terror organisation." The Hamas-run Palestinian health ministry estimates 9,061 people, including 3,760 children, have been killed in Gaza. Lapid said as Israel was fighting Hamas in a densely populated area there was "going to be casualities". "Of course we are sorry," he said. "We have no fight with babies, we have no fight with civilians. We are doing our best to avoid hurting the civilians, this is exactly the difference between a terror organisation and a law-abiding democratic country. "I am acknowledging the fact that the innocent are suffering and I am urging you to direct your questions about it to Hamas." The United Nations human rights office said on Wednesday that it was concerned that Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp could amount to war crimes. When asked if Israel was heeding international concerns about the growing civilian death toll in Gaza, Lapid said "yes". "But I am not sure we need this because we are concerned to begin with," he said. "This is not something we want to do. "This is not a war we wanted to be engaged in, this was forced upon us. Part of the problem we have going into this war is that we want to do our best to avoid hurting the civilians. "Right now both Israelis and the people of Gaza are victims of Hamas." Watch the full interview from ABC News Breakfast below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Israeli PM says concerns over a risk of genocide should be directed to Hamas

children.content: Israeli opposition leader and former prime minister Yair Lapid has told ABC News Breakfast questions over concerns that people in Gaza are at risk of genocide should be directed at Hamas.
As we reported earlier, seven United Nations special rapporteurs have warned that
Palestinian people in Gaza are facing a “grave risk of genocide”.
"We are worried as well, but the question should be directed at Hamas, not at us," Lapid said on ABC News Breakfast.
"We didn't initiate this, we didn't want this war.
"We are protecting our own people against a murderous terrorist organisation that is killing the innocent and we have no other choice.
"Yes, I think the people of Gaza are in peril, the same as the people of Israel, we are all being threatened and killed by a terror organisation."
The Hamas-run Palestinian health ministry estimates 9,061 people, including 3,760 children, have been killed in Gaza.
Lapid said as Israel was fighting Hamas in a densely populated area there was "going to be casualities".
"Of course we are sorry," he said.

"We have no fight with babies, we have no fight with civilians. We are doing our best to avoid hurting the civilians, this is exactly the difference between a terror organisation and a law-abiding democratic country.
"I am acknowledging the fact that the innocent are suffering and I am urging you to direct your questions about it to Hamas."
The United Nations human rights office said on Wednesday that it was concerned that Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp could amount to war crimes.
When asked if Israel was heeding international concerns about the growing civilian death toll in Gaza, Lapid said "yes".
"But I am not sure we need this because we are concerned to begin with," he said.
"This is not something we want to do.
"This is not a war we wanted to be engaged in, this was forced upon us. Part of the problem we have going into this war is that we want to do our best to avoid hurting the civilians.
"Right now both Israelis and the people of Gaza are victims of Hamas."
Watch the full interview from ABC News Breakfast below:
